MainClaim.text: Bayle's failed attempt to save his career at the Illustrious School of Rotterdam by turning to Erasmus tapped into a long, local tradition of civic pride and produced a picture of Erasmus that would become highly influential, particularly during the Enlightenment.

Bayle'sErasmianism.text: Bayle's appropriation of Erasmus was marked by the politics of his personal predicament, and he chose Erasmus as a source of intellectual ancestry to enhance his own reputation.

Localtraditionofcivicpride.text: Rotterdam elites have persistently cultivated the fact that Erasmus was born in their city, and this tradition has produced a wide variety of initiatives, including the appropriation of Erasmus as a champion of toleration.

Politicallymotivatedinitiatives.text: The appropriation of Erasmus has also produced a wide variety of politically motivated initiatives, focusing on his 'tolerant' and 'cosmopolitan' qualities.

SharedvalueswithErasmus.text: Bayle and Erasmus shared a common penchant for fideism and pacifism, and both were scholars dedicated to the quest of establishing historical accuracy.

ErasmianismduringtheEnlightenment.text: Bayle's account of Erasmus became highly influential during the Enlightenment, particularly in the context of the Republic of Letters.

Bayle'sadmirationforErasmus.text: Bayle admired Erasmus as a historian, and his practice as a historian was influenced by Erasmus' humanist historiography.

SharedvalueswithErasmusasahistorian.text: Bayle and Erasmus shared a deep felt awareness of the fragility of human nature, which was reflected in their historical practices.

Conclusion.text: In conclusion, Bayle's failed attempt to save his career at the Illustrious School of Rotterdam by turning to Erasmus tapped into a long, local tradition of civic pride and produced a picture of Erasmus that would become highly influential, particularly during the Enlightenment.
